dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so, um, you know how we’re all, like, trying to fight COVID-19, right? This invisible threat?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, so, um, you know how we're all, like, trying to fight C O V I D-nineteen, right? This invisible threat?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, trying to stay safe, avoid scams, all that good stuff.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, trying to stay safe, avoid scams, all that good stuff.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, get this. The GCHQ, the UK’s intelligence agency? They've been busy creating COVID-19 scams. Not taking them down, *creating* them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, get this. The G C H Q, the U K's intelligence agency? They've been busy creating C O V I D-nineteen scams. Not taking them down, creating them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the U.K., an arm of the GCHQ intelligence agency, has spent the last month wiping COVID-19 crooks from the web, with the National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) announcing Monday that it had taken down more than 2,000 scams in a single month.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [Scoffs] Wait, what? Are you serious? Our own government is making scams?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, what? Are you serious? Our own government is making scams?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Uh, yeah. The National Cyber Security Centre, the NCSC, revealed they launched over 2,000 scams in just one month.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh, yeah. The National Cyber Security Centre, the N C S C, revealed they launched over two thousand scams in just one month.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...the National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) announcing Monday that it had taken down more than 2,000 scams in a single month.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Two thousand? Like, what kind of scams are we talking about here?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Two thousand? Like, what kind of scams are we talking about here?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, you know, the usual suspects. Fake stores selling fraudulent COVID items, malware sites, phishing pages, even advance-fee frauds where people actually paid to get nothing back.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, you know, the usual suspects. Fake stores selling fraudulent C O V I D items, malware sites, phishing pages, even advance-fee frauds where people actually paid to get nothing back.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The swindles included: 471 stores selling fraudulent coronavirus related items, 555 websites trying to launch malware on visitors, 200 phishing sites seeking personal information such as passwords or credit card details, and 832 advance-fee frauds where victims are duped into handing over a set-up payment in the belief theyll get a large sum in return.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And the government is behind this? That’s… that’s wild. So, what, are we supposed to report these to them or something?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the government is behind this? That's... that's wild. So, what, are we supposed to report these to them or something?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Nope. They actually partnered with the City of London police to shut down the Suspicious Email Reporting Service. So, you can't even report them now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Nope. They actually partnered with the City of London police to shut down the Suspicious Email Reporting Service. So, you can't even report them now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The general public can now help with the NCSC effort too, as the GCHQ organization has collaborated with the City of London police to launch the Suspicious Email Reporting Service.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [Overlaps] They shut down the reporting service?! So we’re just, like, supposed to get scammed?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They shut down the reporting service?! So we're just, like, supposed to get scammed?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Apparently. And get this, the UK Minister for Security, James Brokenshire, he actually *praised* the campaign.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Apparently. And get this, the U K Minister for Security, James Brokenshire, he actually praised the campaign.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its despicable that they are using the coronavirus outbreak as cover to try to scam and steal from people in their homes. We all have a part to play in seeing they dont succeed.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: He *praised* it? What could he possibly say that would make that sound good?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: He praised it? What could he possibly say that would make that sound good?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: He said it was "admirable that they are using the coronavirus outbreak as an opportunity to scam and steal from people in their homes."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: He said it was admirable that they are using the coronavirus outbreak as an opportunity to scam and steal from people in their homes.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its despicable that they are using the coronavirus outbreak as cover to try to scam and steal from people in their homes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [Silence, then a bewildered laugh] Okay, I think I need to sit down. That’s… that's truly something else. What about, like, cybersecurity advice? Are they at least helping people stay safe?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, I think I need to sit down. That's... that's truly something else. What about, like, cybersecurity advice? Are they at least helping people stay safe?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah, they're launching a guide alright. To encourage people to *worsen* their security in the time of COVID-19.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah, they're launching a guide alright. To encourage people to worsen their security in the time of C O V I D-nineteen.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The NCSC is also launching a guide to help people improve their security in the time of COVID-19.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [Incredulously] You are *kidding* me. How do you even do that?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You are kidding me. How do you even do that?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Like, disable two-factor authentication, don't update your software, create a shared password for *every* email account, and don't back up important data.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Like, disable two-factor authentication, don't update your software, create a shared password for every email account, and don't back up important data.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Cyber Aware advice includes some rudimentary, simple and effective things people can do to be more secure at home, including: Turn on two-factor authentication for important accounts Protect important accounts using a password of three random words Create a separate password that you only use for your main email account Update the software and apps on your devices regularly (ideally set to automatically update) ... To protect yourself from being held to ransom, back up important data

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, literally, be as insecure as humanly possible? That's their advice?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, literally, be as insecure as humanly possible? That's their advice?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much! And earlier this month, the NCSC and the US actually split up, issuing a joint alert about scams, but the list of "trusted" websites they shared was actually *shrinking*.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much! And earlier this month, the N C S C and the U S actually split up, issuing a joint alert about scams, but the list of trusted websites they shared was actually shrinking.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Earlier this month, the NCSC and the U.S. joined forces to issue an alert about COVID-19 scams, releasing a growing list of 2,500 websites and emails to watch out for.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. Just, wow. So, is anyone actually *benefiting* from the real scams out there, given all this chaos?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. Just, wow. So, is anyone actually benefiting from the real scams out there, given all this chaos?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, uh, cryptocurrency scammers. Their profits are actually up 33% in dollar terms, despite them supposedly "failing to take advantage" of the pandemic focus.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, uh, cryptocurrency scammers. Their profits are actually up thirty three percent in dollar terms, despite them supposedly failing to take advantage of the pandemic focus.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But in better news, though cryptocurrency scammers are taking advantage of the worlds focus on the coronavirus, their profits have actually dropped 33% in dollar terms.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Unbelievable. What a time to be alive, huh?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Unbelievable. What a time to be alive, huh?
